human user studies in fact um I was an undergrad in the lab when
another Stanford uh uh affiliate by the name of Steve Collins was finishing up

fortunately by taking the charm lab from Baltimore to uh Palo Alto or here
Stanford I've had the opportunity to start the hammer lab and so uh um you

trained uh through Stanford I just wanted to take a minute and sort of acknowledge all of the students in my

faculty member one of the greatest things we talked about this at lunch is the students that come out of your lab I also have the great Fortune of having
one of my first PhD students who's now here doing the Stanford biodesign Fellowship uh whose work I'll talk about
towards the end of the talk uh here as well so with that I will get in because I know I got to make up a little bit of time time so we know that we use our
hands and upper extremity to do a lot of dexterous manipulation tasks throughout our daily experience right
um if I were to think about it and cartoonize it right like we think you know oftentimes we observe objects in
the environment through vision um and then if you want to reach out and grab or manipulate objects in the world we send these efferent signals from the
brain out to the periphery at the same time we've got sensors embedded in the musculoskeletal system in the skin itself that sends all of this afferent
information uh back to the brain and does closed loop sensory motor control the blue Trace here the afferent signals
is what my lab really focuses in on and I'll show an example and I'm going to rush through it you might have already seen this work this is the famous role
in Johansson experiment where you lighter you strike a match uh you have the participants try to match right everybody's sort of seeing this I'm
seeing nodding of heads here pretty simple right then you anesthetize the fingers ask them to do it again
performance is markedly worse right and all you've done is sort of turn off the
cutaneous receptors that are in the fingertips okay just for the second time I'll keep
going um so how we get to tell the robotics I know I'm sort of preaching to the choir in this community here
um we know that there are certain environments where you can't directly manipulate right uh uh either because they are located great distances pose
dangerous to the bodies or on different scales from the body or we've contrived accesses in the case of minimally uh invasive surgery there are also cases
where the body itself changes confirmation um and there we're sort of operating in our normal environment just without our healthy intact limbs as we
normally would in both of these cases what you need is an interface that takes your action and imparts it on the
environment these interfaces are originally called tele operators for the sake of time I'm going to skip over the video of the gerk style tele operator
but these devices were sort of invented in the 50s and 60s by a scientist by the name of Raymond Gertz that allowed
operators to handle radioactive material what's nice about these tele operators is that they were purely mechanical just
cables and linkages connecting the leader side of the robot to the follower and so you had great tracking in the
forward Direction sort of position mapping but also great uh you know Force reflection uh from the remote side back
to the operator right um most of these tele operators nowadays because of electromechanical actuation
schemes are actually tele robots um in our lab we like to think of a prosthesis as a tele robot you're operating a distal robotic hand for more
of a proximal location on the body typically using something like EMG as the interface uh
um and so with tele robots right we've gotten really good at doing one-to-one position mapping in the forward path we
measure all the interactions between the environment and the Telly robot but we don't really oftentimes pass that information back to the user and that's
what my lab focuses on as well as alices and others is how do we build these haptic interfaces to restore the sense
of touch to the operator to be able to restore this dexterous closed loop or excuse me this closed loop dexterous
manipulation capabilities in my lab we sort of focus in on two sort of uh
tele-robotic application areas Upper Limb Prosthetics and minimally invasive surgery and then we also do a lot of
work in sort of fundamental haptic perception and I'll talk about that as well starting with the Upper Limb Prosthetics work this is work that was
led by my former PhD student and postdoc Dr Neha Thomas and so if you were to
have an amputation today in the upper extremity there's sort of two types of devices there's a body power device which is his name implies uses Body
Action with the Bowden cable and a shoulder harness to open and close uh prehensor or their model electric
devices body power devices have inherent haptic feedback my electric devices don't and so a lot of our work is
focused on how do we restore this haptic information in the my electric device we you know it has been shown many times
over that when you add haptic information into a my electric device you do get improvements in task
performance we've shown that other labs have shown that as well we wanted to ask a sort of separate question in this
study was is well how good is that performance compared to what we consider the gold standard which is the intact limb right so how close are we getting
back to what you can do with your natural Limb and we also wanted to ask that question sort of looking at not
only task performance so like how well do you do the task but also saying if you do the task really well what
cognitive effort does it take you to do that level of performance right and so this is some work that we've done in collaboration with my colleague Hassan
ayaz who's at Drexel University where we start looking at what we term neural efficiency so in order to get a certain
amount of task performance you have to give up a certain amount of cognitive effort it and we're looking at the relationship between the two good task
performance with very low cognitive effort is very neural efficient um you know bad task performance with
high cognitive load is very un you know you know it's not efficient at all right and so now we want to say what is the
trade-off between task performance and cognitive load um we ran a simple experiment here where
it was a stiffness identification a really stiffness discrimination task where in the top right you see these
little silicon blocks that had three different stiffnesses we asked participants to Alternative Four Shorts Paradigm squeeze one of these two
objects tell us which one is stiffer right um we did this through a prosthesis that you see uh on the left hand side here
that allows us to work with individuals without limb difference or not MPT participants or able-bodied individuals
and you can see sort of in the top left we use this neural Imaging approach called ethnia's functional near for a
spectroscopy which basically looks uh in the prefrontal cortex and can uh
basically do the neurovascular coupling can sort of tied uh um uh you know metabolic activity to neural activity uh
in the bottom left we have a Piezo resistive Force sensor that we put on the finger because again we're trying to compare performance between the
prosthesis with feedback prosthesis without feedback and then the natural limb in the bottom right this shows what
the setup looks like where you reached in with the prosthesis you squeeze the object we move the object out put another object in you squeeze and then
we ask you of course the question which is this which one was stiffer one or two and you answer what we found again you
know I didn't mention this but the objects that we were using were all different mixtures of silicone so they weren't linearly spaced apart we
basically got a trimodal distribution depending on what object pair we asked we got different results so I'll focus
in on the one that was the hardest of the two the soft medium these two were stiffer where the stiffnesses were
closest together what we find is that if you look at the blue trace on the left hand side this is the natural limb
you're 100 accurate right every time we ask you to do it with your real hand you could identify which one you know which
of the two software medium was a stiffer we asked you to do it again with the prosthesis without haptic feedback which
is the yellow polka dot Trace there and what we find is that participants were about at the guessing rate remember it's
a two alternative Force choice so probability probability wise you have a 50 50 chance every time you guess of
getting it right and that's what we see but when we add the haptic information back in we see a significant improvement
over the case where we don't have haptic feedback we're also significantly worse than the natural limb but we're sort of
heading in the right direction this result by itself is not really novel right others have shown this in various
other types of tasks but now when we look at brain activity and I'll for the sake of argument just focus in on that
soft medium combination again what you're looking at here is a delta or a change
in hemoglobin uh concentration before and after we ask you to do the
comparison so we take a baseline measure before we ask you to do the comparison take another measurement after you have
done after you've made your guess and we look at how much that concentration has changed over time and basically what we
see is that the natural limb again the blue Trace here is relatively no different from zero it doesn't take any
cognitive effort to do the task when we ask you to do it with the prosthesis without haptic feedback it has the
largest Delta now we didn't have haptic information but we also didn't turn off any auditory or visual cues so what we
think is happening is participants are actually trying to make the best educated guests that they can with the limited information that they have and
that's why the cognitive effort is being driven up so much in that scenario they aren't just like randomly guessing but
when you add the haptic feedback in we do get a significant decrease in the cognitive effort right still
significantly worse than the natural limb but significantly better than the prosthesis without having feedback and
when we look at the overall what we call Neural efficiency where zero here represents the mean neural efficiency
for all of the tasks what we see is that the natural limb has the highest neural efficiency we would sort of expect that
the prosthesis without having feedback has the worst neural efficiency and the prosthesis with haptic feedback has
better than without and is heading in the right direction of the natural limb um so we sort of shown now that uh this
haptic feedback not only does it have a task performance benefit but the task performance benefit also comes with a
cognitive effort benefit as well okay we sort of been taking this
experiment now um and going with more complicated tasks remember that one was just stiffness discrimination we have a new task now
that we tried out where we have an object and this is sort of modeled after the uh sort of famous Roland Johansson
grasp and lift papers where you can sort of take the weight out of an object without knowing it and sort of see what happens we have a drawer here uh that
has a weight container in it where we can take weight in and out the device also has sort of this unique little
hinge door on it and I'll show you in the video what that does if you squeeze too hard with the prosthesis the door uh
will collapse um so essentially what we've done is create a brittle object so sort of like picking up an egg right where we can
actually change the mass or weight of the egg in real time um what we've also done
in this scenario is start looking at not only just direct manual volitional control with EMG but also what happens
now if you put some level of autonomy on the prosthesis as well um the type of autonomous system that we
had running here was more of an imitation style learner where if you grab the object successfully picked it
up and put it back down the system remembered what was the graph what were the uh the grasping force that allowed
you to be successful so that the next time you go try and uh pick it up you sort of initiate it and then the
autonomous system kicks in and picks it up for you I shouldn't say picks it up it grips it for you you still have to
pick it up um and so this video just sort of kind of shows you what this hat what happens here
um the first time the user is using uh sort of direct haptic feedback so they're getting vibration feedback of
grip Force here to be able to judge what is the right grip force and then the second time that they go do it uh the
autonomous controller kicks in and sort of goes directly to the right grip force uh or the grip force that they used the
last time that allowed them to be successful if they aren't successful you can go retrain it and everything like that
okay um so we had an experiment where we basically told participants we gave them
a minute and said how many times can you successfully pick it up and put it back down in that one minute we did seven Trials of that basically what we found
um is that really the case where you have this haptic share control in the sense of
um you know the autonomous plus the volitional control with haptic feedback we got significantly better uh task
performance in terms of lifting the objects so you were more likely to actually lift the object when you had the haptic share control scheme going at
the same time um you know not significantly lower cognitive load uh but sort of heading in
the right direction in terms of lower cognitive load um the reason that we think it sort of ended up not being significant is
because the first time that you go grab it you it's all manual you're getting haptic feedback and you sort of have to
judge what is the right grip for us and so we think that sort of is driving it up even though over the course of time
it drops off because now the autonomous system is kicked in um but when we look at the neural efficiency we do get a significant sort
of improvement with this haptic share control over the case where we don't have uh haptic feedback um so sort of
similar result that I showed before now but with a more complicated task where it's not just sort of can you
discriminate the stiffness of this object but can you hit this sweet spot in grip for us where if you don't grip hard enough you don't pick it up but if
you grip too hard you actually break it okay we've then started trying this
workout with actual amputee participants um we had we invited a participant in
over the summer um and uh had this participant try this with their clinical prosthetic limb uh
hand which is an I think it's an island Ultra and um I don't think the sound is working
but um what you will see is basically every time they try and grab it and you can maybe hear it here it just breaks
foreign so by and large with their clinical Pro
with their clinical prosthesis they were never actually able to sort of Judge the right amount of grip force to be able to
pick the object up we then had this participant do the same task same object the only difference is we use our
experimental lab prosthesis with the haptic share control algorithm running on it um and we got a sort of different result
in that about 50 percent of the time this participant was able to actually pick it up and put it back down it
wasn't perfect and you'll see here at the end after they put it back down um you know they still were able to like
sort of break it every now and then which you can see happen right there but about 50 of the time they were still
able to successfully pick it back up um so we sort of you know um we're starting to follow this experiment up
now with more amputee participants to see what is the benefit we've also done some other work that I don't have time
to talk about today where we looked at other types of haptic share control uh not just one where it's sort of you know
volitional or fully autonomous where you've got volition that autonomy sort of working symbiotically together and we
get sort of interesting results there as well the last thing I'll talk about in the prosthetic space has to do with the
design of the prosthesis and the prosthetic hand itself right this is the B bionic hand which is sort of on you
know one of the best let's say uh commercially available hands that you can get right um what's interesting about the bionic
is that its actuation scheme looks very different from that of the hand right even though the form is about the same
and that's because our hands use a Agonist antagonist tendon structure to actually control limb movement what's
really nice about this Agonist antagonist structure is that not only can we control position of the limbs but
if we co-contract both sides of the muscles we can actually control endpoint impedance and it's been shown actually
by Allison uh when she was at Hopkins that participants modulate their impedance in real time based on the
needs of the task and so we begin to say what if you could build a prosthesis that allows you to do this impedance control uh in real time this is the
first sort of prototype of such a device where we have basically an anthropomorphic skeleton an open hand
that we found online that might I had a student then rig up to do tendon control right now it's all or you know it's only
uh all four fingers at the same time open or close um and so we've got two tendons here serving as the flexors and the extensor
tendons in the prosthesis um the if you'll notice this this work
kind of got published in 2020 so this happened right before the uh pandemic and everything got shut down so we never
got a chance to actually run the user study but we did get a chance to make a decent video and I'll show you what this
what this control scheme looks like and I don't know if this is the best
control method this is just the one that we kind of stuck with uh in the interim
all right and I stopped the video right here because when we were filming this we didn't notice this until after we
filmed it but this interesting thing happened right and it sort of originates right here where this arrow is going to
point uh watch what happens when I let the video go with the hand
you see how the fingers draped over the surface of the The Ridge of the box if this were normal commercial prosthesis
that would have never happened it would have drug the Box completely off the table right but this is what our limbs do sort of all the time right
um they're rigid they're stiff whenever we need them to be they're compliant whenever we need them to be right they adjust to the environment they adjust to
the task and this is sort of our first sort of approach at seeing a limb that can actually you know our you know going
towards a limb they can actually do this and adjust to the needs of the task okay I'm gonna start now going into
robotic minimum invasive surgery area this is work done by my PhD student Sergio machaka as well as a former
visiting Master student in my lab Guido kashiniga who's now actually doing this PhD with Catherine kookenbecker at the
MOX plank um so we know that da Vinci doesn't have any haptic feedback right um so one of the areas that we started
working in on and this started in my postdoc is looking at surgical training what happens if you give surgeons
feedback during the training phase and does it lead to improvements in performance so we have a very simple
setup here where you can take sort of any inanimate training tasks like the peg transfer tasks that you see here put
it on top of this platform there's just an ATI mini 40 sitting underneath so we can measure all of the interaction
forces between the prosthesis uh uh excuse not prosthesis that the surgical
instruments impart on the task material and then using this device that was created by Andrew Stanley and Catherine
cookenbacher many years ago it's just a risk worn device that squeezes we can basically map the force that you produce
on the task to the amount of squeezing that we produce on the wrist right pretty straightforward this is how the
device you know looks sort of in situ right when uh when you're actually doing the task and what we did is we invited
participants in all novice uh to perform this task as you see in the top right
which is called ring roller coaster or ring walk depending on who you ask to or when you ask but the idea is that you take a ring and you're moving it along
the track and you don't want to generate any Force you want to leave the ring sort of in the center of the track not
making contact um we had two groups of participants perform this task one that had haptic
feedback all the time and one that didn't because we wanted to see does it improve sort of the pace at which they
in they get better at the task compared to the control group that doesn't get any haptic feedback
um and we were looking both at not only the um their task accuracy in this case
so how well did they do the task but also looking at um in this in this situation the speed at which they did the task so is there a
speed accuracy trade-off here um and by and large what we found uh is that the group that gets the feedback
which is this red bar line that you see down here they produce lower forces the entirety of the experiment so yeah 12
Trials of this task the minute they started and they were trained with the feedback so they knew what it was what what kind of information it was
providing but the minute we asked them to do the tasks they you know produce significantly lower forces than the
control group and they did it for the entirety of the 12 trials um so then we said okay well if they do
really well with forces what does this mean in terms of the amount of time that it actually takes them to do the task if they're being very careful and you know
producing less Force maybe they are being slower as well and in fact that's what we found they actually started off
very slow um in fact significantly slower than the control group but what was interesting is that over the course of the 12 trials
they actually got got faster at a faster rate than the control group and so we
think what's happening here is something about the happening information is actually helping them pay attention to
those critical areas in the tasks where most people get hung up and snagged and once they solve that they're able to
actually do the remainder of the task much faster um sort of on a different area of the
surgical training Paradigm when you look at surgical training how it's done clinically there's sort of two choices right you can do it uh either through VR
means which is what a lot what happens a lot in the clinical setting or you can train on the actual physical robot which
is often considered the gold standard we sort of said are these two things equivalent right is training in the
virtual reality World equal to this equivalent to training in the physical world and this is some work that Guido
did when he was visiting my lab where using the dvrk platform he basically designed a task that had both physical
and digital analogs um and so what you see here is for the same input now we can actually do the
task and we scaled everything appropriately so there was no position or geometric scaling here
um the exact same task in the virtual world or in the in the physical world and then we ran a study where we
basically had participants train in one world real or virtual and then we had
them do a crossover where we looked at their performance in the other world right so if you trained on the physical platform then we asked you to do the
task in the virtual platform vice versa if you train in the virtual world we had you do the task in the physical platform
um you'll see the word sham here uh because Guido had this really crazy idea that what happens now if you actually do
brain stimulation while people are doing the task so we have a group now that's doing no stimulation in a group that's
getting cerebral uh transcranial direct current stimulation which has been shown to improve motor learning and this is in
collaboration with a colleague of ours Pablo selvnik who's at uh um Hopkins down in physical medicine and
rehabilitation same Paradigm with and without brain stimulation what we found and we asked I should back
up I'm going a little too fast we asked participants to do the task at three different speeds uh fast slow uh and
then moderate with moderate sort of represents what is the nominal speed that you would see the task being performed clinically
um the task itself is just a needle driving task like I showed you um I will focus in on the moderate case
here uh because this is where we found some of the more interesting results what we see is that on the left hand uh
bar plot here what you see is that we took a baseline measure asked them to do it about 15 times looked at their performance then ask them to train for
about 40 trials and then did an evaluation did they get better after training and by and large from the red
to the green we got a significant Improvement they got better after training right then we said now go from
the physical platform to the virtual platform and we looked again at the error metric that they produced and what
we found is that it was no different in the VR world than it was in the inanimate World they didn't get significantly better it didn't get
significantly worse right in terms of their parametric in the virtual world that's not the case they did get
significantly better after training Baseline to evaluation got significantly better but the minute we asked them to
do the exact same task from the VR I mean from the VR world into the inanimate World they actually got
significantly worse the error the errors went up um so we're sort of saying that there's
something unique about the transfer from VR to the real world that we're not fully capped from yet now I don't know
exactly what it is I think a lot of it has to do with sort of the way we render Dynamics in the VR world and how you
learn to account for those Dynamics because it's been shown that surgeons learned to account for those Dynamics in
the real world VR has its limitations right if anybody's ever sat on one of these VR trainers you know you know if
you ever told a suture the way the suture sort of floats through the air right doesn't act the way a real suture does then we said okay now what happens
when you do um the the brain stimulation I'm only showing you the results for the virtual
platform because this is where we saw the biggest bang for the book is that remember again on the left-hand side
I've already showed you this Baseline to evaluation you get better but the minute we ask you to transfer from VR to the
physical world you get worse but that's only the case when you don't have simulation when we provided the
brain stimulation uh what you see is they got better from Baseline to evaluation and then when we ask them to
go from VR to the inanimate World there they didn't get better significantly better or significantly worse so we're
starting to see results that sort of look like the transfer that happened from the uh inanimate to the VR World
um how all this works I'll be honest I'm a mechanical engineer not a neuroscientist
I don't fully completely understand but uh you know what we're starting to think of is the cerebellum sort of does this
role in sort of helping you pre-plan right and it does model pre-planning
um and what we think is happening is by doing the stimulation you sort of over activate the cerebellum and it sort of
learns this feed forward Model A lot better than when you don't have the stimulation
um and so you've got a much richer model when you go in and do the task now regardless of the environment itself
okay last but not least I'm gonna uh jump into the uh fundamental happy

you notice is the environment the reality is Right transparency is sort of is a theoretical ideal
um in fact we do notice the leader and the follower of most silly operators and in fact most leader tele-operator systems actually add Dynamics
um and so we begin to ask what is the impact of these added Dynamics to task performance and perception in order to
answer this question um Mohit spent the better part of the covet era building this setup here that
we call the tele operator test bed um I would describe it to you you can think of it as a single degree of Freedom teleoperator that has an input
it's just a yeah an input here an output here that we can render as both the virtual environment or a real

Rod that connects the two sort of like the Gert style mechanical tele operator we have two DC motors we sort of represent your standard tele-robotic

um this is sort of what it looks like from a different uh point of view so you can sort of see um we sort of did system ideal to the
system to show the show uh that we do in fact do get different uh transfer functions and different Dynamics out of
it each of the transmissions and then we ran this task where Mohit basically
asked uh participants to do an object tracking task where we did both single
sign tracking and some of sign tracking we kind of went into this with this sort of I call it naive now uh hypothesis uh
that the transmission that was rigid remember the one that sort of was just a physical Rod connecting input and output
would actually allow for better performance because there's no Dynamics really it's just inertia
um and that one of the other two the electromechanical or the physical system with actual Dynamics in it um stiffness
and damping would perform worse what we actually found um and sort of highlighted here uh is
that regardless of the transmission users adapted right um and this was sort of this not like
you know we sort of struggled with this for a while trying to figure out what to do with this because it wasn't the result we were hoping for but it's sort
of an interesting result still that shows just how robust human control actually is so much so in fact that what
we can see in the right hand side here when you look this is just the errors and what you see is that overall regardless of the transmission the users
were able to adjust for the Dynamics of the transmission do the task and the way they did it is and what we

on the input side that users had to do in order to get the output to basically
perfectly track um uh the object and what you see is that's where we actually find differences based on the tele operator

systems Dynamics in order to do the task now I will say most of these participants only spent maybe six seven

can basically have you sit with a mirror in between your body have your hands located different this is apart and as

your across the mirror as your other hand because you're looking at the reflection right um so that's this phenomena it's called
Uh the mirror illusion it's called proprioceptive Drift they also use it in lower extremity uh for lower extremity
amputees so to help with Phantom limb pain and things like that um and then there's of course the rubber
hand illusion which I'm sure many have heard of right where if you simultaneously stroke your real hand and
a rubber hand over time you learn to quote unquote embody the rubber hand and think of it as your own
Mohit started asking this interesting question right if synchronous brush Strokes um you know in the rubber hand illusion
